segment.source: 4697(S) A service was installed in the system.
segment.target: 4697(S) A service was installed in the system.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4697(S) A service was installed in the system.
segment.target: Describes security event 4697(S) A service was installed in the system.

segment.source: 4697(S): A service was installed in the system.
segment.target: 4697(S): A service was installed in the system.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates when new service was installed in the system.
segment.target: This event generates when new service was installed in the system.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that was used to install the service.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that was used to install the service.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that was used to install the service.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that was used to install the service.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Service Information:
segment.target: Service Information:

segment.source: Service Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of installed service.
segment.target: Service Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of installed service.

segment.source: Service File Name Type = UnicodeString: This is the fully rooted path to the file that the Service Control Manager will execute to start the service.
segment.target: Service File Name Type = UnicodeString: This is the fully rooted path to the file that the Service Control Manager will execute to start the service.

segment.source: If command-line parameters are specified as part of the image path, those are logged.
segment.target: If command-line parameters are specified as part of the image path, those are logged.

segment.source: Note that this is the path to the file when the service is created.
segment.target: Note that this is the path to the file when the service is created.

segment.source: If the path is changed afterwards, the change is not logged.
segment.target: If the path is changed afterwards, the change is not logged.

segment.source: This would have to be tracked via Process Create events.
segment.target: This would have to be tracked via Process Create events.

segment.source: Service Type Type = HexInt32: Indicates the type of service that was registered with the Service Control Manager.
segment.target: Service Type Type = HexInt32: Indicates the type of service that was registered with the Service Control Manager.

segment.source: It can be one of the following:
segment.target: It can be one of the following:

segment.source: Value
segment.target: Value

segment.source: Service Type
segment.target: Service Type

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: ​Kernel Driver
segment.target: ​Kernel Driver

segment.source: ​A Kernel device driver such as a hard disk or other low-level hardware device driver.
segment.target: ​A Kernel device driver such as a hard disk or other low-level hardware device driver.

segment.source: ​File System Driver
segment.target: ​File System Driver

segment.source: ​A file system driver, which is also a Kernel device driver.
segment.target: ​A file system driver, which is also a Kernel device driver.

segment.source: ​Recognizer Driver
segment.target: ​Recognizer Driver

segment.source: ​A file system driver used during startup to determine the file systems present on the system.
segment.target: ​A file system driver used during startup to determine the file systems present on the system.

segment.source: ​Win32 Own Process
segment.target: ​Win32 Own Process

segment.source: ​A Win32 program that can be started by the Service Controller and that obeys the service control protocol.
segment.target: ​A Win32 program that can be started by the Service Controller and that obeys the service control protocol.

segment.source: This type of Win32 service runs in a process by itself (this is the most common).
segment.target: This type of Win32 service runs in a process by itself (this is the most common).

segment.source: ​Win32 Share Process
segment.target: ​Win32 Share Process

segment.source: ​A Win32 service that can share a process with other Win32 services.
segment.target: ​A Win32 service that can share a process with other Win32 services.

segment.source: (see: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms685967(v=vs.85).aspx
segment.target: (see: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms685967(v=vs.85).aspx

segment.source: ​Interactive Own Process
segment.target: ​Interactive Own Process

segment.source: ​A service that should be run as a standalone process and can communicate with the desktop.
segment.target: ​A service that should be run as a standalone process and can communicate with the desktop.

segment.source: (see: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms683502(v=vs.85).aspx)
segment.target: (see: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms683502(v=vs.85).aspx)

segment.source: Interactive Share Process
segment.target: Interactive Share Process

segment.source: A service that can share address space with other services of the same type and can communicate with the desktop.
segment.target: A service that can share address space with other services of the same type and can communicate with the desktop.

segment.source: Service Start Type Type = HexInt32: The service start type can have one of the following values (see: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms682450(v=vs.85).aspx):
segment.target: Service Start Type Type = HexInt32: The service start type can have one of the following values (see: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms682450(v=vs.85).aspx):

segment.source: Value
segment.target: Value

segment.source: Service Type
segment.target: Service Type

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: ​ Boot
segment.target: ​ Boot

segment.source: ​A device driver started by the system loader.
segment.target: ​A device driver started by the system loader.

segment.source: This value is valid only for driver services.
segment.target: This value is valid only for driver services.

segment.source: ​ System
segment.target: ​ System

segment.source: ​A device driver started by the IoInitSystem() function.
segment.target: ​A device driver started by the IoInitSystem() function.

segment.source: This value is valid only for driver services.
segment.target: This value is valid only for driver services.

segment.source: ​ Automatic
segment.target: ​ Automatic

segment.source: ​A service started automatically by the service control manager during system startup.
segment.target: ​A service started automatically by the service control manager during system startup.

segment.source: ​ Automatic Delayed
segment.target: ​ Automatic Delayed

segment.source: ​A service started after all auto-start services have started, plus a delay.
segment.target: ​A service started after all auto-start services have started, plus a delay.

segment.source: Delayed Auto Start services are started one at a time in a serial fashion.
segment.target: Delayed Auto Start services are started one at a time in a serial fashion.

segment.source: ​ Manual
segment.target: ​ Manual

segment.source: ​Manual start.
segment.target: ​Manual start.

segment.source: A service started by the service control manager when a process calls the StartService function.
segment.target: A service started by the service control manager when a process calls the StartService function.

segment.source: ​ Disabled
segment.target: ​ Disabled

segment.source: ​A service that cannot be started.
segment.target: ​A service that cannot be started.

segment.source: Attempts to start the service result in the error code ERRORSERVICEDISABLED.
segment.target: Attempts to start the service result in the error code ERRORSERVICEDISABLED.

segment.source: Most services installed are configured to Auto Load, so that they start automatically after Services.exe process is started.
segment.target: Most services installed are configured to Auto Load, so that they start automatically after Services.exe process is started.

segment.source: Service Account Type = UnicodeString: The security context that the service will run as when started.
segment.target: Service Account Type = UnicodeString: The security context that the service will run as when started.

segment.source: Note that this is what was configured when the service was installed, if the account is changed later that is not logged.
segment.target: Note that this is what was configured when the service was installed, if the account is changed later that is not logged.

segment.source: The service account parameter is only populated if the service type is a "Win32 Own Process" or "Win32 Share Process" (displayed as "User Mode Service.").
segment.target: The service account parameter is only populated if the service type is a "Win32 Own Process" or "Win32 Share Process" (displayed as "User Mode Service.").

segment.source: Kernel drivers do not have a service account name logged.
segment.target: Kernel drivers do not have a service account name logged.

segment.source: If a service (Win32 Own/Share process) is installed but no account is supplied, then LocalSystem is used.
segment.target: If a service (Win32 Own/Share process) is installed but no account is supplied, then LocalSystem is used.

segment.source: The token performing the logon is inspected, and if it has a SID then that SID value is populated in the event (in the System/Security node), if not, then it is blank.
segment.target: The token performing the logon is inspected, and if it has a SID then that SID value is populated in the event (in the System/Security node), if not, then it is blank.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4697(S): A service was installed in the system.
segment.target: For 4697(S): A service was installed in the system.

segment.source: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.
segment.target: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.

segment.source: We recommend monitoring for this event, especially on high value assets or computers, because a new service installation should be planned and expected.
segment.target: We recommend monitoring for this event, especially on high value assets or computers, because a new service installation should be planned and expected.

segment.source: Unexpected service installation should trigger an alert.
segment.target: Unexpected service installation should trigger an alert.

segment.source: Monitor for all events where “Service File Name” is not located in %windir% or “Program Files/Program Files (x86)” folders.
segment.target: Monitor for all events where “Service File Name” is not located in %windir% or “Program Files/Program Files (x86)” folders.

segment.source: Typically new services are located in these folders.
segment.target: Typically new services are located in these folders.

segment.source: Report all “Service Type” equals “0x1”, “0x2” or “0x8”.
segment.target: Report all “Service Type” equals “0x1”, “0x2” or “0x8”.

segment.source: These service types start first and have almost unlimited access to the operating system from the beginning of operating system startup.
segment.target: These service types start first and have almost unlimited access to the operating system from the beginning of operating system startup.

segment.source: These types are very rarely installed.
segment.target: These types are very rarely installed.

segment.source: Report all “Service Start Type” equals “0” or “1”.
segment.target: Report all “Service Start Type” equals “0” or “1”.

segment.source: These service start types are used by drivers, which have unlimited access to the operating system.
segment.target: These service start types are used by drivers, which have unlimited access to the operating system.

segment.source: Report all “Service Start Type” equals “4”.
segment.target: Report all “Service Start Type” equals “4”.

segment.source: It is not common to install a new service in the Disabled state.
segment.target: It is not common to install a new service in the Disabled state.

segment.source: Report all “Service Account” not equals “localSystem”, “localService” or “networkService” to identify services which are running under a user account.
segment.target: Report all “Service Account” not equals “localSystem”, “localService” or “networkService” to identify services which are running under a user account.
